subtitle: Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery, with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be looking at advances in remote
viewing, and I'm delighted to be with Lyn
Buchanan, who has made the journey here to Albuquerque.
Lyn is the author of The Seventh Sense, a book about remote viewing, as well as a
book of scientific fiction called Gravity Can Be Your Friend.
He lives in Alamogordo, New Mexico.
Welcome Lyn.
Well, thank you for inviting me.
It's always a pleasure to be here and talk to you.
It's a pleasure for me too, and a big pleasure for our audience as well.
Every time we have you on the channel, I get a very strong audience response.
Thank you very much.
For good reason.
You've been engaged in remote viewing practically
from the beginning of the government project.
Well, no.
It had been in existence 10 years before I got there.
You got there in the mid-80s then?
About eight years after me.
Oh, yeah.
You're a newcomer.
I'm a youngster, yeah.
Well, of course, I've studied remote viewing
from you, and you have been teaching remote
viewing.
I'm a dilettante, you're a professional.
That's the difference.
I had been a teacher by trade before that, and also a computer specialist before that.
When Joe McMoneagle left, I inherited the unit
database, and when people started coming in
after me, they were teaching it, you know, Ingo had lost his contract.
And so, instead of Ingo teaching, the other guys in the unit were teaching.
And they were having trouble with it.
And so, they said, well, you try it this time.
And it worked, and the newcoming people, incoming people had no problem with it.
And so, I became the unit trainer, yeah.
And at the same time, to my understanding, you were in close contact with Ingo.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
Ingo was a good friend, yeah.
So, starting with your involvement in the unit at Fort Meade and up until his death.
Yeah.
And you've had the opportunity, therefore, to
observe the evolution of the field of remote
viewing over decades.
The field of remote viewing with Ingo was constantly changing.
And you talked to the different people in the unit, you know, who came from the unit,
and each one of them will tell you a little bit different story.
That's because Ingo never fully finished the development of CRV.
And so, he'd teach one person, by the time he
got to the next person, he had made changes.
By the time he got to me, he was teaching six stages of remote viewing to the unit.
He had developed up through 18 stages.
He said he'd never teach anybody.
And so, when I saw him the last time, I was talking about stage five.
And he said, oh, I got rid of that.
We don't have that anymore.
And he had taught everybody in the unit stage five, so an integrate stage.
But he was still developing controlled remote viewing.
And you, I gather, have been developing it further since his death.
I have found, I'm a database person, I'm a database freak.
And I have found that Ingo was a genius, really was.
And I have found that almost anything, psychic
functioning-wise, that does not follow the
Ingo Swann method works at chance, pretty much at chance.
But you get a method that follows the Ingo
Swann technology that he developed, it's going
to work, and amazingly so, yeah.
A lot of the stuff we're doing now is not what Ingo originally taught, but it's based
on everything he did.
And it's working, it's great.
Well that's the important thing, that it is working.
Yeah, it's the results that count, yeah.
And I imagine that, at least in part, one of
the reasons that he would teach it a little
differently for each person is that there are individual differences in people.
That's one reason, but he was also constantly
experimenting, constantly keeping his own
data, keeping his own documentation and records
and all that, and trying things a thousand
times.
And if it worked 750 times, that wasn't good
enough, and, you know, still needed improvement.
He was always trying for 100%, and he's human
like the rest of us, so, you know, never reached
it.
But yeah, there, especially near the end, you
should see some of Ingo's work, just phenomenal
stuff.
I'm glad that the, which college is he in?
West Georgia.
West Georgia, yeah.
I'm glad that they're taking all of his stuff.
His archives, yeah.
His archives.
Rice University is taking the, building the
archives of the work that was done, not Ingo,
butâ€¦
Ed May's archives.
Ed May's, Russell Targ's, Hal Puthoff's, mine, Paul's, Joe's, stuff like this.
And they're building, actually, I think a
bigger archive than they're building in West
Georgia.
And the interesting thing is that there are archivists at these different universities
dealing with paranormal information and they're communicating with each other.
That's right.
Yeah.
And it's becoming, thanks to, I think thanks
to Ingo Swann, who made this into a science,
and you know, Russell and Hal, due to their
work and, you know, with, you know, the people
they worked with, this is becoming respectable.
And I know that many police departments,
psychic is still a four-letter word, you know.
Oh, this came from a psychic?
It's called CCT, crumple, crumple, toss.
But you say it came from a controlled remote viewer?
Oh, really?
Let me read that.
And it has gained the respect.
A lot of the stuff you see on the internet tears down that respect.
But most of us who are doing the controlled remote
viewing, working very quietly, non-disclosure
agreements with corporations and units and
police departments and all that, and we don't
talk about the work, you know, give details,
but it's gaining a reputation among researchers,
police departments, the medical establishment, space research, oh, yeah.
Space research is absolutely interested in this
because we have viewers who have database-proven
track records in their accuracy, not just,
you know, somebody who says, oh, yeah, I once
did something and it turned out right.
And I know we've talked in the past about
how careful you are about keeping a database
of your current students and anyone else who's gone through the CRV protocol.
I think it's absolutely necessary.
I really do.
It takes it out of the woo-woo realm and it
makes it a real thing with real applications.
Now, I should bring this up, though, because
on the other hand, we did an interview.
I didn't do the interview myself.
It was brought to me by Debra Katz, currently
the president of the International Remote
Viewing Association.
An interview she did, we released on this channel with Angela Ford, who was part of
the remote viewing program.
She's a natural psychic.
Yes.
She's pretty good.
Yeah.
And Ed May took her to Russia with him.
He considered her one of the top people.
I would say she's one of the top natural psychics.
Yeah.
She was never a remote viewer, a controlled remote viewer.
No.
And that's my point.
In fact, she told me that she was in the unit,
but she would do channeling and the other
people in the unit were not happy with the
fact that she wasn't following their protocol.
Well, it wasn't so much that as the fact that
the military requires everything to be uniform.
And the channeling is not uniform.
There are no protocols for the reporting.
The work she did was quite often extremely good.
But you couldn't put it into the format that the army would take.
And so, you know, the information just didn't
fit categorically into paragraph one, paragraph
two, paragraph three.
And so it was always a problem.
I'm told it was instrumental in apprehending drug smugglers.
Oh, yeah.
Absolutely.
She's good.
It was useful.
It was useful.
But it wasn't formatted.
Okay.
And so that was the problem.
She's got talent.
She's good.
She's really good.
Yeah.
Then the value of the protocol, as opposed to working with people who have a natural
gift, can you go into that a little more deeply?
Yeah.
The protocol, basically, everybody has their
own special talent and their special abilities.
And we've never met anybody who doesn't have intuition.
And the controlled remote viewing that Inga Swann developed will develop your intuition
to the highest level that you have.
And so many people come for the remote viewing
training, and all of a sudden they're doing
work that's equal to a natural psychic.
And they say, oh, you made me psychic.
No, we didn't.
We just taught you how to use what you already have.
That's all we do.
We don't make anybody psychic.
You already are psychic.
And so when we find somebody, especially somebody
who has a high natural talent, has never used
it and doesn't know it, and they develop into
a superstar, they're convinced we made them
psychic.
We didn't.
We just taught them a method for using what they have.
Well, it's fascinating that people can have
enormous psychic talent and not even realize
it.
I had an interviewer ask me one time, he was
asking me all the different things that happened.
And he said, why do you think these things happened to you?
And I said, these things happen to everybody.
I wasn't trained by my mother to ignore them.
And I was always inquisitive.
And when something like that happened to me, I paid attention.
And I didn't deny it.
And I think these things happen to everybody.
All these natural, you know, you talk to anybody,
oh, yeah, one time, you know, what happened
to me, and it gets you over in the corner.
You know what happened to me one time?
That's true.
And I think a psychologist will attest, and I
know there are studies, surveys, that suggest
that 70% of the population report having had a
paranormal experience of one kind or another.
And I suspect the other 30% won't report it, won't report it, right.
For whatever reason, they push it out of their mind.
Well, it's against their religion, or they were taught, oh, that's your imagination.
And you know, hey, that's not businesslike,
you'll never get anywhere in life, you know.
And also, people are going to make fun of you and ridicule you and all that.
And yeah, as a society, we stomp it out, I mean, actively stomp it out.
Coming here, a person I was writing with, he said, you know, back in ancient times,
we were talking about it, and they didn't have radio, TV, newspapers, or anything.
And yet, they were able to tell where the enemy was, where the herd was going to be,
that we could get food, you know, and they used their intuition and developed it.
With the coming advent of other means of communication, we don't use it anymore.
And so, it's becoming, you know, just vestigial.
An atrophied skill.
An atrophied skill.
Ingo Swann, if I recall, sort of complained
about the idea that the human population has
a lot more potential than it has ever actualized.
Fantastic potential, yeah.
Everybody complains about the situation we're
in these days, but complaining is not actually
doing something about it.
Complaining louder is still not doing something about it, you know.
Well, you are.
You're training people.
That's doing something about it.
That's doing something.
And somebody was asking me in a webinar I had recently, well, if it all hits the fan,
will there be any survivors?
And I said, there's one way to be sure there's going to be survivors.
He said, how?
And I said, be one.
That's all it takes, just be one.
There comes a point in the training that I do, Lori's husband has a term for it that
can't be repeated on camera, but there comes
a point where all of a sudden, one of the
students, well, every one of the students
goes through this point where all of a sudden
they realize, I can do this.
And you know, it's not woo-woo, it's not fake, I'm not here being gypped by some
gypsy and all this, and they realize, I can do this.
And immediately they realize, wait a minute,
all that stuff I've been taught, and all
of a sudden there's this paradigm change.
And that moment is one of the moments I live
for in teaching, because you can see it happen,
and it's great, I love it.
When does that happen typically?
Generally after about 10 times when they've really nailed a target that was in a sealed
envelope, absolutely no way that they could have known it.
I don't know what's in it, nobody in the room
knows what's in the sealed envelope, because
it's just totally picked them random out of hundreds of targets.
And they nail it, they describe it, they draw
it, and then we open the envelope, and they
look at it, and about the 10th time that happens,
it's, oh, what Laurie's husband calls it.
And it's that moment, and you can see it.
I mean, everything from their childhood suddenly
vanishes, and it's different, and oh yeah.
And they look at themselves differently, and
they all of a sudden realize, hey, I've got
this potential.
And from that point on, I know I'm going to have a good viewer.
From that point on, we're going to be bringing
home some missing kids, you know, missing
soldiers, yeah.
Now, in my own experience as a graduate student,
back in the mid-1970s, I did an eight-week
training program.
And what I found was that from day one, they could do it beautifully.
And Russell Targ used to, you know, do little
weekend workshops with people, and they're
instantly doing highly accurate remote viewing.
But then it dawns on them, wait, what have I done?
What have I done?
I can't do this.
Yeah.
And they get rid of it.
Yeah.
But about the 10th time they do it, all of a sudden, they can't deny it anymore.
And all of a sudden, it starts to have meaning.
And that, oh, moment changes, you know.
And it's a beautiful moment.
I love it, seeing the student go through that
change, when all of a sudden they realize
they are more than they ever thought they were.
I love it.
I live for that.
Well, one of my thoughts long ago, and one I still hold to, is that as you open up to
metaphysical reality, you come to realize
that among the other talents that are natural
for people is something along the lines of healing.
And I know you've also been engaged.
You told me a wonderful story earlier about some work you did in that area.
It would be well worth sharing with our viewers.
We have a lot of work that we do in that area.
And in the Inga Swann technique, you never heal anybody.
If it's, you know, they've got a missing arm, I don't care.
You can hear all these miracle stories, you're not going to replace that arm.
Come on.
Yeah.
But when you get down to it, a large percentage
of our illness today, we can blame it on the
pharmacies, we can blame it on the smog and, you know, and all that.
A lot of it is self-generated.
And so with the Inga Swann technique, you access
their subconscious mind and you find out whether
or not it's self-generated.
And if it is, you spend the time and you
may do 200 or 300 sessions with that person.
It's a lot of work.
But you help them work out the problem at the subconscious level.
And all of a sudden, they start healing themselves.
And you know, with a psychic, I'm going to heal this person.
That person needs that illness, they get sick again.
If you help a person through this and they heal themselves, it becomes permanent.
Not only that, but you have taught them how to heal themselves.
And so it's not that one problem that gets healed.
It starts a chain reaction and changes their life.
It's fantastic.
And the method that you use, you described to me as a scenario.
That's one of the methods we use is a scenario.
Do you want me to go through that?
I think our viewers would be fascinated.
Okay.
A man named Savely Salva out in California
set up this organization where he rigorously
tested psychic healers, picked only the cream
of the crop, the ones who could actually prove
that they could do things.
And he started matching them up with professional
doctors who would work with them and keep
data and do further research on them.
Well, he hooked me up with Dr. Mann of Cornell University in New York City.
This is back in the 1980s, isn't it?
This is 95, 96.
It was after I got out of service.
He was working hypertension.
He had patients in all the time who had systolic
levels way above 200, 250, 260, and all this,
you know, at crazy levels.
And so whenever he got a patient, they had this machine that every 10 seconds, I think
it was, it kept a graph of their record.
And he had a long history of their records on this machine.
Blood pressure.
Blood pressure.
He would call me and say, I've got a patient on the machine.
I would flip a coin, and if it turned up heads, I would work a session on them.
I never told him.
If it turned up tails, I wouldn't do anything.
At the end of the six-month period, we, you
know, put the data together with his charts,
when I worked, when I didn't work, and all that.
And when I didn't work, their record stayed their normal record.
When I did work, it would often, quite often,
amount in up to 50-point drop in their blood
pressure.
It was never enough to cure them.
It wasn't a curative thing.
But in a case where they were about to have a
stroke, it would get them out of the critical
area.
And that was his summary at the end was, this
isn't curative, but in an emergency, it can
be used.
And so, we got that as a scientific study on
the use of CRV to help in medical applications.
What would you call this, CRV?
It was actually what's called remote influencing.
But now, this scenario situation is a situation
where you access them at the subconscious
level, and you develop a story, and you get them involved, you get their subconscious
involved in the story, and it can't be your own imagination.
You do your part, and then you wait for their response.
And so, I set myself up on a road, and this
woman, I pictured her driving toward me, just
hell-bent for leather down this road, and she
stopped, and I waited to see what happened.
And she leaned out the window and cussed and yelled and screamed at me.
And so, at that point, how did I react?
So, I reacted by saying, look out this way, there's deer out there.
And, I don't care, you know, and all this.
And finally, I just kept on.
Finally, her response was to get out of the
car, come look, and there were deer out there.
And she got kind of fascinated with it.
And I said, okay, well, let's go down and get near them.
So, we went near them.
That scared them.
And so, I said, well, let's go hide behind a tree, there's a forest over here.
And once we got into the forest, we heard water splashing.
There was a waterfall back there, and a little lake-type thing.
And by the end of that session, it took, once you
got into that and got access to her subconscious,
it took no more than 10 minutes.
And at one point in that, she jumped into
that lake and just started swimming and having
a good time.
And on that one thing, her blood pressure
had dropped 50 points in about five minutes.
And I engaged her in a subconscious scenario.
Now, we have a lot of other tools for the medical applications, too.
But that one's a very specific one.
And I mean, you're ad-libbing the entire time,
because you do something, you wait for their
subconscious response, and then you try to
figure out, what do I do next to engage them
at the subconscious level?
And with the Ingo training, you can do that.
But it is definitely a, oh, it's total ad-lib all the way through.
But it heals people.
It gets them to heal themselves.
And this is one of the medical applications that we have.
But we never try to heal a person.
We try to get them to heal themselves.
There was a parapsychologist, Jerry Salfin, who
did a report years ago in Northern California
at the time, is where he was based, although I think originally from New York.
And his theory was that this is how healing works.
It's a telepathic suggestion to the other
person who then heals themselves, as opposed
to a psychokinesis model, where I'm going to heal, slap them on the forehead, heal.
Well, I suppose it's possible that both techniques can work from time to time.
But in any case, you also reported to me that
afterwards, the patient gets debriefed about
their experience.
Well, yes, we did in that case.
First of all, they had to give permission to be involved in a test.
We did everything legally.
Savely was absolutely squeaky clean on his
research and the legality of it and everything
else.
I don't know whatever happened to his work,
but at the ranch I'm building, this is another
thing I want to do, is not only train people
in the medical applications of CRV, but take
the cream of the crop, start hooking them up
with the medical professionals, and continue
Savely's work by documenting rigorous, strict
documentation showing that, yes, an intuitive
person can be an extremely valuable tool for a doctor.
Of course, with the end goal, train the doctors to be intuitive.
Train the nurses.
A doctor gets trained in one method.
That's his hammer, and everyone who walks in the door is a nail.
A heart doctor, I don't care.
You have a bum foot, oh, it's your heart.
But the nurses, you teach this to a nurse who
will then guide the doctor, and that doctor's
practice becomes successful.
The uses for this is phenomenal.
So what I hear you saying in short is that Ingo
Swann developed not just a single technique,
but a repertoire.
He did, and he developed a base technique
that a lot of people out on the internet say,
oh, if you don't keep it strictly Ingo, then you're doing wrong and all this.
He developed a base to build on, and I liken
it to, you know, you learn something in medical
school, okay, every single day there are new developments in medicine.
That doesn't negate the human body and the study of the human body.
You know, there's a basic that you learn in medical school.
If all you learn as a doctor is what you learned
in medical school, you're not going to be
a good doctor.
You've got to keep up with the developments,
you've got to keep up with things.
And so my practice has been to go out to corporations, to the police departments, to
different agencies and research groups and all that, find out what they need.
And it hasn't always been easy to civilianize
the military use of remote viewing.
When we first brought it into the civilian
arena, we were working for police departments.
That's no different from the military.
But then we had, you know, we've done space research, we've done medical applications,
we've done research and development for different corporations.
A couple of corporations have come and said,
we would like a remote viewing team of our own.
Now, that's where I have the non-disclosure agreements.
I mean, it's really strict.
And they have developed, you know, I've trained
the remote viewing units like we had in the
military for a corporation that is now using
that remote viewing unit in secret within
their own company to devise company plans and procedures.
Well, I can understand the need for secrecy
because there are people out there who would,
if they knew what such a corporation was doing,
would make every effort to publicly ridicule them.
Oh, yeah. Absolutely. Yeah.
That this is, you know, superstitious nonsense.
We're still in that age, yeah.
We still live in a culture that is infused with a deep sense of denial.
That's right, yeah.
And this is one of the things that the work
that we do for corporations and agencies and
all that, even with police departments, they
don't want people to know that they use remote
viewers.
They're eager to get controlled remote viewers,
but that four-letter word, psychic, is still there.
And so we sign non-disclosure agreements.
I also, when it comes to the police, I require
non-disclosure agreements from them because
the information we provide, we don't know if they have dirty cops.
We don't know if the names of the viewers are going to come up in a trial.
Criminals learn who gave the information.
That puts their viewers in danger.
And so I require non-disclosure agreements of
the police departments to protect my viewers.
I think it's unfortunate, but it's realistic
to say we live in an era in which secrecy
around remote viewing actually protects everybody.
That's right.
Yeah.
And I find it unfortunate too, but if you're
going to be realistic and database this and
be scientific about it, hey, that's part of it.
That's the realism.
So we do it.
Yeah.
And you're particularly interested in working
with people who are professional, who have
a professional need that they're not able to resolve using conventional methods and
who understand the value of working with a team of people who are following a rigorous
protocol.
That's right.
Yeah.
We were approached by a space research company
who have â€“ this company has plans for astronauts
not to go to Mars, but beyond Mars, to another star system.
They already have it planned.
And so they said, we know there are planets around this star.
We think we can get people there within one lifetime.
It's one of the nearest stars.
And they said that when you send an ambassador
to a foreign country, you give them an area
book that tells the religion, the habits, and customs, and all this do's and don'ts
so that you don't go there and do something stupid and start a war.
And they said, can you find out if there is a sentient life system there?
And I said, yeah, we can take proven remote viewers who have above 80% accuracy.
And with a known 80% accuracy, we can predict.
And we found that on the second planet out from that star, there was a sentient race
of beings, not bright.
On our scale, it would be probably IQ of 90.
Not smart.
These are not space-faring aliens and all that.
But they have their own society.
And so they said, okay, can you do an area book?
Can you do a demographic?
So we did.
And we gave it back to them.
And of course, there's no feedback.
There won't be for, who knows.
Until they get there and come back, which will be a long time.
And so I wasn't satisfied with that.
And so I took some of my best students and I said, okay, sealed envelopes, okay?
I'm going to get all the data I can on a culture on Earth here.
And I want you to do the demographic on it.
And then I said, okay, I'm going to get another
culture here and that I know that part of
that culture moved into this culture, okay?
And one of the first ones we took was when the Mormons broke apart and moved up into
Calgary, you know, British Columbia.
They're among, you know, farmers and all that.
And so we had absolute records of those.
So, in other words, you're looking at the interaction between Mormons and the Native
Canadians.
That's right.
Where they migrated.
And totally blind.
And the viewers, we said, okay, give me the
demographics of these people and the demographics
of these people.
And we made charts.
And we said, okay, let's lay this chart over this chart.
Those areas that matched, we found out, was
exactly where they cooperated with each other.
Those areas that didn't match was where crime
happened, where bigotry happened, and all
of this.
And it dawned on me, like, we've got people
coming across the southern border and they're
just randomly sending them to New York City and all this other...
We can do the demographic on groups of people to keep crime down and all this.
Turks coming into England.
You're using the term demographic, and I know
what you mean, and you know what you mean,
but I don't think our viewers quite know what you mean.
The demographic of a society, or even a single
person, is the collective total of their religion,
their customs, their upbringing, their traditions,
their political beliefs, their desires in
life, every aspect of their life.
And you do that, and you can actually make a chart.
We call it a polar chart.
And the shape that comes up on that chart
shows the absolute personality of that person
or that culture.
In other words, you're using remote viewing to do a very detailed sociological analysis
that if you had to use conventional means would be very costly.
Oh, yeah, absolutely.
Time-consuming.
You'd have to send researchers out, surveys,
and you'd be collecting information.
So the remote viewing process, in other words,
can shortcut all of that with a high degree
of accuracy.
One of my students recently did a project,
a museum wanted an artifact from some of the
North African tribes who were very belligerent to outsiders.
Well, how did they send one of their people in to get the artifact and talk them out of
borrowing the artifact for the museum without getting them killed?
And so we did a demographic of the people at the museum, we did a demographic of the
people of the tribe, and came up with an answer.
Here's how you do it to get that artifact borrowed for the museum without getting the
guy killed and all this.
And what we realized was, well, for example,
this one company said, we know we've got aliens
on the earth, and sooner than later, probably
presently, they're filtering into our society.
Once they start doing it openly, can you give us their demographic, our demographic,
and see where the conflict is going to be?
And you know, once you find the conflicts and
the cooperations, advertisers can advertise
the cooperation area and advertise for humans and aliens, and sell products.
Realtors can say, no, wait a minute, we don't
want to put those in New York City, we don't
want to put them in Podunk, South Carolina, you know, we want to put them in this area.
And realtors can sell houses.
Police will be prepared for what areas of
discord there's going to be between when two
societies clash, and can train their cops to be prepared to settle those disputes.
Churches, when one religious group moves into
another religious community, there's going
